vehicles.name: Scout Corvette
vehicles.desc: Small, fast, and designed to see without being seen. She carries sensor arrays that outmatch vessels twice her size and enough engine to outrun anything she can't fight. The scout corvette is the first ship into unknown space and the first to run when the shooting starts.
vehicles.notes: The scout corvette is your player starting vessel. She's fast, she's agile, and she forces the players to rely on brains over firepower. Every encounter is a decision: observe and report, or engage and risk losing the only eyes the fleet has in this sector.

vehicles.name: Armed Freighter
vehicles.desc: A cargo hauler with guns bolted on — sometimes by the manufacturer, sometimes by the crew. She carries freight between systems and mounts enough weaponry to discourage casual piracy without being so well-armed that customs officers ask uncomfortable questions.
vehicles.notes: The armed freighter is the Millennium Falcon archetype — a working ship with teeth. She has cargo space for trade, smuggling, or mission supplies, and weapons that make pirates think twice. She's the campaign vessel for groups who want commerce and combat.

vehicles.name: System Patrol
vehicles.desc: The law enforcement vessel of settled space. She cruises the shipping lanes, checks manifests, investigates distress calls, and responds to piracy reports. Not powerful enough for fleet combat, but she carries boarding parties and the legal authority to stop and search.
vehicles.notes: The patrol ship is your encounter vehicle. She appears when the players are doing something they shouldn't, or she's the ship they serve on in a law-enforcement campaign. Her boarding shuttles and tractor beams make escape difficult without violence.

vehicles.name: Blockade Runner
vehicles.desc: Speed over everything. She sacrifices armour, weapons, and crew comfort for engines that push her past anything in normal space. Built to carry critical cargo through interdicted systems, she relies on being too fast to catch rather than too tough to kill.
vehicles.notes: The blockade runner is your speed-run vessel. She wins by not fighting — every encounter is a chase. Her low Toughness means a single hit could be fatal, so the tension is constant. Perfect for smuggling, intelligence, and wartime resupply missions.

vehicles.name: Pirate Raider
vehicles.desc: An ugly vessel purpose-built for ugly work. Oversized engines, boarding equipment, and weapons designed to disable rather than destroy. She hunts trade lanes, hits fast, strips the cargo, and vanishes before the patrol fleet responds. No one builds these for legitimate purposes.
vehicles.notes: The pirate raider is your recurring antagonist. She appears, fires disabling shots, and closes to board. The players can fight from inside a captured freighter, hunt her as patrol crew, or fly her themselves in a piracy campaign. Her weapons are tuned to disable — she wants the cargo intact.

vehicles.name: Courier
vehicles.desc: A single-crew vessel built for one purpose: getting a message, a package, or a person from one system to another as fast as physically possible. She's tiny, she's fast, and she carries exactly one critical thing that someone needs very badly.
vehicles.notes: The courier is your plot delivery vehicle. Whatever she's carrying is important enough to justify a dedicated ship — intelligence, diplomatic pouches, prototype technology, or a person who must not be intercepted. She creates urgency: the cargo has a deadline and the enemies know her route.

vehicles.name: Mining Vessel
vehicles.desc: Industrial equipment in space. She carries cutting lasers, ore processors, and enough cargo space to make an asteroid-mining run profitable. She's not armed, she's not fast, and she's the economic backbone of every frontier colony that doesn't have an agricultural base.
vehicles.notes: The mining vessel is your frontier workplace — and your horror setting. Something goes wrong on a remote mining ship and the nearest help is days away. She's also the prize in piracy scenarios and the source of distress calls that lead to adventures.

vehicles.name: Science Vessel
vehicles.desc: Laboratories, sensor arrays, and a crew of specialists who are more interested in anomalies than combat. She's lightly armed, heavily instrumented, and drawn to exactly the kind of unknown phenomena that get people killed in space.
vehicles.notes: The science vessel is your exploration campaign ship. She finds the weird things — anomalies, derelicts, pre-cursor artefacts — and the players investigate. Her crew are scientists, not soldiers, which means when violence happens they're badly out of their depth.

vehicles.name: Customs Cutter
vehicles.desc: Small, fast, and carrying scanning equipment that can read a ship's cargo manifest through the hull. She intercepts vessels at system checkpoints, inspects for contraband, and calls in the heavy patrol ships when she finds something the crew would rather she hadn't.
vehicles.notes: The customs cutter is your low-level antagonist for smuggling campaigns. She can't stop a determined freighter by force, but she can call for backup. The players need to evade her scans, bluff their way through inspection, or outrun her before the reinforcements arrive.

vehicles.name: Personnel Shuttle
vehicles.desc: A short-range transport that ferries crew between ships, stations, and planetary surfaces. She carries twenty passengers in discomfort, has no weapons, and her only defence is being too small and too worthless to bother shooting at.
vehicles.notes: The shuttle is your transition vehicle — she gets players from the ship to the station, from orbit to surface. She's also your escape pod, your boarding craft in a pinch, and the thing the players are desperately piloting through debris fields when everything else has gone wrong.
